content:
, 2015
												I love and loved this game. I played it back when it it first came out around when I was 5 or 6 (1998-1999) and even when I go back I am surprised by how advanded the software is on such an old game. The second one is amazing as well. The third one, Deadly Shadows, .... ehh give or take, I mean it is a Thief game and if you care for story get it, I loved it regardless of it's somewhat shoddy gameplay. The newest one, the reboot (forth game), is pretty good as well. Although I will admit it has it's downfalls like being too close in stealth systems to Dishonored, and having a slide system (almost Dishonored teleport system with limitations), and it is still an amazing game, but doesn't provide the same backstory for Garrett. In the old games (this one in particular) there was a reason Garrett was a thief and also how he became a master thief, but in the reboot it is lost. If you played the new one and are curious to how to old games stack up BUY IT! If you never played any of them but love stealth games BUY IT! If you have have never played a Thief game and have never played a stealth game or are not normally interested in stealth games BUT IT! I promise for $7 you will not be disappointed. This game is worth much more than that due to quality, but for as little as it costs you will never feel guilty you bought it.I will admit, the graphics quality is subpar in comparison to today's video games, but if graphics quality means little to you and you care more for gameplay and story quality BUY THIS GAME!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 17, 2015
												When the first Thief game came out, my brother convinced me to get it.  Glad I did and extremely happy that years later I was able to get it on Steam, and it being Thief Gold at that. I had followed all the games that came out after I had got the first one, but moving from overseas back to the states, they got lost :( so being able to have them available whenever through steam is nice. Only one I did not get was the newest Thief that came out not to long ago. Being an original fan of this series, the new one did not appeal to me personally.It's a stealth/some what horror game, where you do your best to remain in the shadows and not be seen. At times you may get caught and have to fight, but the main goal is to get what you are looking for, get in wihtout being seeen, and then get out the without being noticed. Also collecting treasures and goodies along the way. The music fits the mood nicely, and depending on which one in the series you are playing or the level, you may come across some pretty weird, eerie stuff along with interesting steampunk style looking contraptions.One of My favorite things in this game was the passages that are apart of the animated clips before and after the missions. Especially from the Woodsie Lord or the hammerites. Shows the weird but interesting creativity behind the makers of the game.I feel if you ever played this way back in the day, its worth having for nostalgia, or just because you liked it so much.For those who have never played it, or played the new one to find out about the old ones, you might not like it so much. The graphics are rough and at times there might be glitching. Sometimes its funny glitches. On some missions I even ran through the end or goofed off with guards chasing me because the way the run or things they say looks hilarious.I'd suggest if you feel you might be interesting in this game, check on some play throughs of it that are available online first, to make sure it might be something you'll like.

content:
er 24, 2015
												Thief - The Dark Project was the first game I ever purchased for PC. I am happy to see that it is now able to be incorporated into the Steam Library of games. To this day my daughter, who spent many hours on "dad's" lap watching TDP with her sippy cup, is still a fan of the Thief series. Obviously this game has a lot of memories, and also a lot of meaning; so I won't even try to be objective...Thief Gold is not an enormously fast moving game, so if you are the type of player that wants to "knock 'em all dead" and hurry up and finish, I'd think you would dislike Thief Gold. It takes time. Waiting out guards, finding loot, and at times failing and dying. If you're not familiar with Thief Gold, you may want to save often.The graphics are not bad for '98, and keep in mind that you don't fix up a '67 Thunderbird to look like the modern Mazda version of Thunderbird today. Thief Gold is a piece of gaming history. A landmark for patience and problem solving in the gaming world. So... put the super graphic modern games on the shelf of your mind, and step back in time to an era when you were able to overcome the developers design in your own way!

content:
8, 2015
												Thief is one of the many master pieces that makes the video game industry still worth defending over the stupid assasin's creed and Call of duty Bullsh*t lately. It is the only game that has really balanced stealth with good combat if you get yourself in a jam. The game is really old though, so the graphics might take some getting use to, it reminds me of when video games were introduced depth and perception and not a 2D side scroller. The controls are messed up like no other in here though, and-from what I can see- there is no way to change it. It's not that they are stiff or stuff like that, it's just they placed the commands in the most awkward postions on the keyboard. I've never really understood the story because, as old as this game is, it just throws you into a level and expects you to know what's going on so when something happens I kind of misunderstand and it takes me a minute to realize what just happened. To understand the story you mostly have to read what you are going to do on the current mission, and why. But what makes up for it is the gameplay and the stealth in this game. Few games today can actually have good stealth and still manage the game with decent combat if you gor yourself in a pickle, Thief puts that right on the mark if you have to run and hide, you can do it. If you need to fight your way out, you can do it. Overall score: 80/100

content:
ber 2, 2015
												Thief Gold was my first Stealth game. I didn't know the simple joy of extinguishing a torch and clubbing some guard unconscious before scrapering with an entire mansions worth of loot in my pocket.Thief Gold despite it's age and need for a patch (which is easy to download from the looking glass studios Forums) is a stella experience. It is a well paced game with hints and clues to the story scattered through out this richly created world. The first missions get you to grips with the mechanics of the game with all the gadgets and weapons at your disposal. Garrett is a great playable character, always there to crack wise at certain people or situations to lighten the mood in those slightly stressful missions. In fact there are so many great characters, from the Blackjack fodder to the prisioners. What I will say is that there are some missions that feel more of a chore than others, especially those concerning the walking dead. These unkillable things were the bane of my play through. It did during those missions become more of a hack and slash type game, despite Garretts terrible combat ability.Overall though I would highly recomend Thief Gold as a gateway stealth game. It is quite simply a masterpiece.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
7, 2015
												One of my most memorable gaming experiences from back in the day....and I only ever played the demo!! That's a fact, but even after all these years that brief experience with this game stuck with me. Just from what little I experienced back then I quickly realized that Thief was far more engrossing and complex then most games at the time of its release and now that I've purchased it and finally played through most of the game up to the time of writing this review, my mind has truly and completely been blown by its level of depth. The stealth tactics you can make use of, such as water arrows for putting out torches and fires, moss arrows to muffle the noise you make as you slowly walk/crouch towards unsuspecting enemies, rope arrows to more quickly complete objectives or work your way around a tight situation, hiding bodies, etc. all make this an unforgettable experience.  The level designs are pretty complex and extremely atmospheric and there are also some fairly challenging environmental puzzles to solve at times too. Even the voice acting and ambience totally sets the mood for your quest for loot and other more notable goodies as you complete objectives.  Oh yeah, and then there's the strong horror element (some of the ambience plays a role here too, as it perfectly sets the mood for those creepier moments) relating to some of the objects you acquire in the game and enemies such as zombies, spiders (including giant ones), skeletons (well, at least 'a' skeleton that tried to kill me at one point) and also demonic and ghostly-enemies.Thief is one of the better gaming experiences from an earlier generation. Even after all these years, it still stands out in the crowd and remains one of the best stealth experiences you'll ever have in a game, bar none!UPDATE (8/8/15): Just beat the game, and if I've learned anything from the many trials and tribulations I faced furing my quest (besides how to properly steal things while being all stealthy and whatnot) it's that Constantine is a major ♥♥♥♥♥♥!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
17, 2015
												There is no better stealth game out there.In Thief, you play as Garret, a legendary thief and a character so famous that even those who never played the series probably heard of him. Garret is the perfect and original thief archetype: Ganancious, egocentric, quick-witted and very, very skilled. Trained by the Keepers, Garret was meant to be an agent for the organization and help to keep order in the city through subterfuge, but he eventually decides that his skills are best employed to steal from others and make a good living out of it. Even though all that Garret ever wanted was to alleviate the rich from their burdens of gold and gems, he finds himself forced to be much more than that when a chain of events place himself at the eye of the storm. The struggle between Order, represented by the Builder, and Chaos, represented by the Trickster, is about to reach its pinnacle and Garret will be right in the middle of it all.The gameplay is pretty much flawless. Changing the keymapping to your liking is probably a must, since some controls are not as intuitive for not following modern patterns. Once you're accustomed to it, you'll soon find yourself immersed in the single most stealth-driven game that ever was and, hell, probably ever will be. Don't you ♥♥♥♥ing dare using your sword on this game unless there's a immediate threath to your life. Thiefs like Garret never kill and are never seen. If you play the game on expert (which is exactly how the game should always be played), you'll be required to see and do everything without ever killing a human being. That is stealth right there. Walk in the hard wood instead of the carpet and your steps will alert guards. Remain in the shadows with your sword out and the blade will shine and give you away. Shoot an arrow off its target and everyone will hear it hitting the wall. This is how stealth should be done, no quick running around no-scoping teleports and instant magic kills (I'm looking at you, Dishonored). All you have in your inventory are some lockpicks, a blackjack and a few different arrow types, like rope arrows for reaching hard-to-get places or water arrows for squishing out torches. That being said, you should probably know that there will be combat, since there are supernatural creatures walking the world and some of them are very, very violent. This is the reason you carry a sword around.Graphics are a little outdated, especially on the resolution support department, but mods can easily fix that. All in all, with a little setup time and a little getting used to, you'll be playing the game like a pro and enjoying every second of it one or two hours after buying it, trust me.Gameplay - 10/10Soundtrack - 7/10Graphics - 4/10Content - 8/10Challenge Level - 9/10Replayability - 6/10

Install Thief Gold (Steam) and maybe set the compatibility mode from THIEF.exe to Win XP SP2 and maybe it can help to deactivate the steam overlay2. Install TFix (v1.22)You will find a download link in the description from the HD Mod below3. Install Thief Gold HD Mod (v1.0)You will find it on moddb.com4. Important: If you experience huge framerate drops, rename dark.gam in the HDMOD folder (for example to: dark-BAK.gam). I searched very long for this solution. :)With these settings, Thief Gold runs very good on my rig.Intel quad-core and GeForce GTX on Win 7

content:
, 2015
												Immensly fun, atmospheric, with a fantastic storyline and universe. Rather challenging with a smart stealth tactic, and really requires the player to be calm, patient (and also load anytime they screw up... which in my case is frequent) and to really listen to where your enemies are (good headphones are a must).The only thing that personally irritates me a bit is the tedioussness of getting lost, especially in very sprawling areas. However, IMO that makes you feel more like a Thief and in a strange way, makes them game feel more like you're in the shoes of Garret. You're not going in there with knowledge of every nook and cranny, you have to explore, get lost, get lost some more, cry, get lost, reload, start over, get lost again, curse at the screen, and then finally find what you're looking for. It's irritating, but realistic.I reccomend this to any fan of late 90's games and especially to anyone who likes the stealth genre.

content:
, 2015
												Thief Gold, an expanded version of Thief The Dark Project, is one of the stealth genre's most successful titles.  Although the game is dated, the gameplay is immersive and the level design is immaculate.  Each mission is designed in a way to allow you the use of all of the tools available to you.  Loot is hidden around each mission, interesting sights and text that provides flavor may also be found simply through the exploration of a level.*****One problem with this version*****The game advertised is not the game you are buying.  You end buying the original Thief The Dark project and -not- Thief Gold.  Thief Gold had added missions and they are missing from this download.  Something else that is missing are the cut scenes between missions.  Not only are the scenes entertaining, but they help to make you care about the game world and characters while furthering the narrative of the story.  Without these cut scenes, someone knew to the game won't understand everything right away and we are all missing an important part of the experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2014
												A masterpiece from start to finish.While it is an old game, it holds up well on both a gameplay and story standpoint, and encapsulates what it means to hide in the shadows perfectly. In recent years, stealth games are fairly simple as far as mechanics go, and quite linear. Here, there's quite a bit of skill needed in order to successfully sneak around, knock enemies out, traverse, and steal which should be expected, given its first person nature. This isn't even mentioning its huge levels with various secrets.It should be noted that of the 3 stealth games released in 1998, this was the first to use shadows (through a gradient) and sound as game mechanics, something that Splinter Cell would use 4 years later.Besides the occasional pathfinding bug and the lack of cutscenes (for which there is a fix), you'll find that the game is finely programmed and definitely worth the price.

content:
ry 20, 2014
												I bought this game purely for the nostalgia of playing it when I was a young whippersnapper. As well as that, I thought I would actually buy it so that I would be able to understand it and maybe complete some of the levels instead of watching it over my brother's shoulder suggesting things when I was like 5 or something. Anyway, it's a fantastic game to burn a couple hours on, the maps are huge with loads of little hidey-holes and rooms to explore and loot, the textures of the guards are hilarious when looking at it now, but back when it was the ♥♥♥♥ and the epitome of PC gaming it was awesome. There's some pretty eerie sound effects and music to accompany you in the shadows which gives the game a little more depth than just sneaking around grabbing all the stashes of coins. It's a great world to escape into and become the stealthy theif mastermind, Garrett sneaking around people's mansions and stealing valuable stuff. Basically everything you want to do but without the ASBOs or restraining orders.Buy this game because it's actually really amazing. I love it.11/10

content:
2014
												A masterpiece from start to finish.While it is an old game, it holds up well on both a gameplay and story standpoint, and encapsulates what it means to hide in the shadows perfectly. In recent years, stealth games are fairly simple as far as mechanics go, and quite linear. Here, there's quite a bit of skill needed in order to successfully sneak around, knock enemies out, traverse, and steal which should be expected, given its first person nature. This isn't even mentioning its huge levels with various secrets.It should be noted that of the 3 stealth games released in 1998, this was the first to use shadows (through a gradient) and sound as game mechanics, something that Splinter Cell would use 4 years later.Besides the occasional pathfinding bug and the lack of cutscenes (for which there is a fix), you'll find that the game is finely programmed and definitely worth the price.

content:
ber 22, 2013
												CHALLENGE.This game is really hard. I like it, because there was no dumbing down for consoles when games like this were around, which means it's nice and hard. (well,  depending hehe). You can get lost, but if you use your brain and study the map, you can 'figure it out'. Make sure to check for secret levers and false panels, hidden passageways, for they more often than not lead to loot or an easy gain.GAMEPLAY.The more loot that you manage to find in each mission, the more equipment you can buy for the next job; Therein lies the reward for your efforts. Being conceited as I am, I personally like completing the game having killed not a single soul, which is possible to do. However, Garret has a Bow and an array of Arrows at his disposal, if you just can't resist the urge to snipe that unwitting guard!Timing is everything. You can rush in like a steam train, but that is just not the behaviour of a Master Thief now, is it...Also, if you play on Expert, then you cannot kill anyone, adding a lesson in Master Stealth. Enjoy :)INTERFACE.The maps are basic handwritten suggestions, aimed at giving you a hint rather than a dumb arrow pointing you the way. The key bindings take a little getting used to. But I am a veteran and I can tell you they ARE easy to get used to. There is free reign on personal key binding. You can save many configurations, depending on how you play. Okay, so the physics are a little rough and ready, but this was the cutting edge of technology and it is all about the stealth. Get used to how the player behaves in the environment and you won't have a problem.GET IT?If you like games with a real challenge, requiring patience, a game that delivers punishment for idiotic decisions, immersive and scary environments with appropriate abience and music, Levels that are varied and difficult, then the Thief series is certain to please you. Thief 1: The Dark project (aka; Thief Gold), 10 / 10.Thief 2: The Metal Age  11 / 10.(These two are the two to focus on).Thief 3: Deadly shadows. (started to stray away from the original themes and level of difficulty, but still close to the originals). 7 / 10Thief 4: I don't even want to recommend this one. Leave it on the shelf with Call of duty and Assassins Creed if I were you...Sorry, it ain't Thief no more.. 0 / 10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2015
												I came to Thief late.  As much as it's praised, and that praise is well deserved... it does suffer from a bad control scheme and some of the problems of retro games.  You should rebind your keys immediately, because you KNOW your hand is going to be reaching for WASD.  This is an easy fix, but it does need to be done right from the onset.  But the bigger problem is that the physics have some serious issues.  They were standard, normal issues for all games of the time.  Younger people who can't remember gaming in the 90's, are likely to get severely frustrated with these issues.  I get frustrated with them MYSELF.  It shouldn't take six tries to jump over a one-foot ledge, but it often does.  You shouldn't fall to your death because of the lack of the game's responsiveness, or because your character's toe was in the wrong place and prevented you from getting up on the ledge, but you do.  We used to take these things in stride because it was the best thing we had.  So if you're less than 25, new to gaming, or frustrate easily, you should probably stick to modern games.  But if you're 25+, or if you can take your lumps with old game mechanics issues (die horribly a hundred times, get ♥♥♥♥♥♥, and come back to it later when you've cooled off, and do it on the first try... you know that's how it goes every single time) you'll love this.  The story and narration are great.  I can't wait to go through the whole series!  You do have to keep in mind that this is from 1998, but I would still recommend this to anyone.  Even if you don't enjoy the gameplay, this is one of those games you hear about constantly, and having first hand experience of a classic game is the best thing.  It's like seeing Casablanca, or playing the Ocarina of Time, for a more game-centric comparison.  When you're looking at its flaws, view it critically, like an old horror movie with cheesy effects.  Let it sit heavily on your mind that it was the best they could do at the time, and don't judge it against modern game standards.  Judge it instead, on the merits it had, compared to other games at the time.  By that standard, this game's amazing.

content:
0, 2012
												Almost twenty years have passed since the release of Thief, and this game still doesn't cease to surprise me.Who needs fancy next-gen controls, focus modes, casual player difficulty or quick time events if you already have this particular gem?Thief is all about pitch-dark steampunkish medieval mythology paired with probably video game history's best stealth gameplay.• Sword, Blackjack and Bow? Check.• High replay factor? Check.• Awesome cutscenes? Check.• Castles, dungeons, temple ruins, all with excellent level design? Check.• Cultists, zombies, ghosts and other hazards? Check.• Loot, loot and loot? Check.• One of the most badass main characters ever? Check.• One of the best PC games ever produced? Hell yeah, check.Make sure you play it on Expert Mode to explore all the secret areas and mission goals. After your first playthrough install Bentraxx' Thief Gold HD Texture Mod for an almost new experience.If you enjoyed the first one, also take a look into Thief 2, Thief: Deadly Shadows and The Dark Mod.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Thief Gold is a first person stealth game. Singleplayer only. Released in 1998.It's quite old but you can believe me: It's nice and worth a try.Graphics:     8/10It's an old game. So I can't compare it with Crysis 3. The textures and effects are really ok.The most important thing here: They created a really nice atmosphere with textures you would describe nowadays with the word awkward.Leveldesign:     7/10Let's split this topic. There are good levels and bad levels.The bad levels are so confusing that I wish I could erase them for good.For our luck these levels are fairly rare.Most levels are really well designed. You have to think and search for the best pathin the shadows hoping to not get detected. Sometimes there are more ways to get to the target location. There are plenty of secrets and loot. I admit that sometimes it's extremely hard to find the correct answer to the riddle and the game becomes frustrating.To sum it up: 7/10.Sound:     5/10On one hand you have really annoying enemy sounds, on the other hand you can locate the enemies' footsteps and the rest gives you a fitting sound ambience. Music is virtually not existent and not necessarily needed in this genre but I miss it. Gameplay/Handling/Equipment:     9/10You are the thief crawling in the shadows. The game wants you to hide and sneak. And I swear you will do it. Otherwise you will have a really bad time playing the game. The enemies are too strong for you to kill them in combat (most of them). You must use the really innovative equipment to take your enemies down and find the best way to infiltrate. But it takes a long time to get used to the controls and "rules" of the game. For example: Killing people with arrows is nearly impossible except you do it from the shadows (1-shot kill). The same thing with the club. Knock people out with one hit from the back or die after trying to kill your enemy face to face. The most important tool is your bow. Use your rope arrows to climb up, use water arrows to extinguish the torches, use the noise arrow to distract enemies, use moss arrows to silence your steps (etc.).Enemies/AI:     9/10Ok - now I have to explain. Nine out of ten is really high.I have to remind you that this game is really old. And it's really amazing that guards don't just ignore dead or sleeping bodies and keep on searching you until they find you. The AI reacts if you miss the shot and I never experienced a real bug. Sometimes the AI has problems with altitude but it's not gamebreaking or noticeable.So for this time: Awesome!BTW.: Most undead are dumb like they are meant to be.Story:     7/10It's a nice story with unexpected twists. Some people may have a problem with the fact that the story becomes science fictional and doesn't remain realistic. The voice actors for the characters are really fitting and it will never be boring throughout the game. The best thing is that you can hear Garrett's thoughts which makes the chacacter lively.Critic summary:     7.5/10     Personal fun rating:     8/10     [very good game]The game is oldschool and one of the first stealth games. And it deserved the name Thief..I can recommend the game for genre-fans. One warning: If you don't have patience then this is not your game. One of my favorites. 31h played (one playthrough). Sadly the replay value is low.

content:
18, 2013
												In 1998, Looking Glass Studios, a company that wasn't afraid to tread new ground in innovation and game design would release one of the most fascinating games of all time that would pave the way for many future titles, stealth and otherwise.Thief is one of those games where you can lose yourself in it's atmosphere quite quickly. Doing steampunk before steampunk was cool, it throws you into this marvellous Victorian styled world of magic and technology as a character you can't help but love; Garrett.As Garrett, you will visit mansions, underground tombs, ruins and abandoned sections of The City, risking life and limb for that final prize; unimaginable wealth.The gameplay is solid and rewarding. Your 'Light Gem' will tell you how visible you are at any given time. Hide in the shadows and sneak past at the right time to avoid your enemies... if you want. You could kill them or knock them unconscious but that's your choice to make. Its perfectly possible to complete this game without killing or knocking anybody or anything unconscious.The story is also very well written however the main story doesn't start until a few levels into the game so you get time to take in the world around you and see a tiny bit of it, time to master the controls and learn how to play.Small story segments are given to you here and there that may tell you things you need to learn about your objective or the environment; two guards having a conversation, a dropped scroll or book on a bedside table. Exploration of the open-ended levels is rewarded either with loot to steal or with tiny story segments.Speaking of loot and gear, you'll need to get exploring and collect it. The more loot you collect in one level, the more money you will have to spend on gear for the next. Gear such as Water Arrows to put out torches, Rope Arrows to climb or to find alternate entries into buildings, Flash Bombs to temporarily blind pursuers, Moss Arrows to silence your footsteps over loud surfaces or Noisemaker Arrows for a quick distraction.The game does have it's flaws; the sometimes confusing level design can make it hard to navigate some levels, a small amount of voice-acting isn't that great, the slight overuse of the undead in places and the character models haven't aged very well but the art design, atmosphere and storytelling still hold up today as some of the best ever encountered in a game.Mods are out there to update the graphics and textures if you want to use them. The game is very mod friendly and there are plenty of user-made fan missions out there to keep your inner taffer happy for a long time. You can also find help on setting up the game on your PC here:


Thief Gold Setup and Modding Guide 
A Guide for Thief Gold
By: Saleck

			Thief Gold was built for  Windows 9x  systems and has a hard time running on modern computers. This guide will help you set up the game using the latest unofficial patches and teach you how to apply mods.		


It may be a little rough around the edges but it changed the way I look at games forever and not many games do that. I can't recommend this game highly enough!

content:
, 2013
												If you missed this one back in the 90s, it still hasn't lost its appeal. There's a reason every review for a modern stealth game includes a comparison to Thief. This is the game that defined the genre.It contains realistic open level design that's never been matched since. Each building feels like it was designed to serve a real purpose, not just to be a linear game level. The backstory is deep and immersive and the motivations behind the steampunk-versus-magic factions are morally complex.One of the all-time great classics. Well worth a purchase.Unfortunately, the engine hasn't aged well. Even with the recent patches, this game requires a bit of tweaking before it runs without mouse lag at the correct speed in widescreen mode. No matter how highly I recommend this game, you need to be willing to spend some time reading the forums and tweaking configuration files to get the most out of it.

content:
12, 2014
												Thief is not a stealth game for the light of heart.  For starters, you may be used to backstabbing enemies in other games, such as Dishonored, which was inspired by this game.You would be better off unlearning that instinct, as this is a game that emphasizes the fact that you are a thief.  Not a "Rogue" from D&D, and not an Assassin from Assassin's Creed.  Garrett is no swordsman, carrying his sword more for self-defense than necessity.The swordplay is intentionally awkward, as they originally developed the engine for another game they had planned, but discovered it was too difficult to use.  Then they realized they could apply it to a game where the player character isn't expected to be a good swordsman.As far as stealth mechanics go, you will learn to love the shadows.  Garrett is practically invisible while in the darkest shadows, and thus you will find yourself flitting from shadow to shadow, like a true thief, while fearing the light that exposes you to your enemies.  You will also learn to pay careful attention to the sound you make, as guards have ears and will pay attention to sounds you make.Being a thief, however, Garrett is squishy.  And on the highest difficulties, he considers himself a professional - that means no murdering.  This is what sets Thief apart from other games - it discourages simple murder, and encourages you to get around obstacles instead of cutting your way through them.  This is a simple thing that Deadly Shadows and Thief 4 have neglected.The graphics are dated, but this can be mended by the HD mod, which improves the quality of the textures.  However, if you can overcome the graphics, you will find a rich and rewarding experience.As far as the plot goes, well,, it is slow to start off with - Garrett takes the first chance he gets to escape from the Keepers, and tries to make his own fate outside of their influence.  The plot of the game doesn't kick in until part of the way in.  More impressive than the plot, however, is the atmosphere.  You are in the !@#$iest steampunk city in the entire fictional universe.  The rich are corrupt, the poor are sick and hungry, one religion's word is law, and another religion is trying to kill everyone.  Even the bears suffer (if you eavesdrop on a conversation in the first proper mission of the game).Even if you are a new player, I would recommend playing the game on Expert.  Expert is where Thief truly shines, as it requires the most gameplay out of you.  It isn't just a flat upgrade in stats, you have more objectives you are required to complete, objectives you might not have ever known about on any other difficulty.What are the bad parts of this game, you might ask?  For starters, the controls are outdated.  You can remap them, but you have different keys for "walk forward" and "run forward", and you WILL be using both.  Thankfully, the game doesn't use TOO many keys, so just remap them to your comfort level.All in all, if you're a fan of stealth games, I would DEFINITELY recommend Thief.  If you are interested in starting a stealth game, I would recommend giving this a try, too.  If you hate Stealth games, why are you reading this?If you want a Thief game where you play as a Thief and not a kleptomaniac Assassin, this is the game for you.

content:
7, 2016
												This game is amazing despite it being old. I never played it before, so I was not going into some nostaligia-trip. At first, since the game was so old, I did not enjoy any of it, until I did the first three missions and I started to get the hang of it. The story is great, the gameplay is fantastic, your inventory of tools is wonderful. On top of it, this game is huge. I never been overwhelmed by a game of such size. There is no map to hold you hand, it is all up to you to figure it out, and the vast size of each map is overwhelming at first. This game is extremely long. It took me 37 hours to beat it, but I played the at the highest difficulty setting. So it will last you a while. Get yourself the "Gold" version, not the original version, the expansion adds to the value of the game. The only weakness of this game is the AI is really stupid, but it does not end up ruining the game for you. I rate this game at 9.5 / 10.

content:
7, 2016
												Like no other game Thief holds a very dear place in my heart.  Nothing in my experience comes close to the sense of otherworldly atmosphere as presented in this game.  I remember when I played this as a 13 year old kid, the visceral sense of breaking & entering Bafords manor, blackjack in hand, the guard on duty who seemed so real in that long dark forboding corridor.  Dark Souls comes close to this but is too grimdark and frankly difficult, and Dishonoured tries too much and loses a sense of immersion.Thief Gold is even better as the extra missions act as good breaks between the supernatural missions towards the end.  Protip about those supernatural missions: think of yourself as more of a Ranger than a Thief: its action time >:)1000/10, best game ever

												This game arguably had more influence on the industry of gaming than The Beatles had on the industry of music. From Splinter Cell to Half Life 2, and from Hitman to Dishonored, numerous other titles have borrowed from or referenced this masterpiece. The story, the charismatic protagonist and the bizarre setting all contribute to a completely unique experience that feels more like the digitalised image of a picture in your head as you read through a dark medieval-steampunk novel. it's mircaulous, and it's aged graphics give it a much needed charm of being "just enough" for your head to complete the picture. Plays like a dream.They dont make them like this anymore.

content:
4, 2016
												Do the cutscenes play?  Nope.  Are there some annoying bugs that make it difficult to play on modern systems?  Yep.  Is it better than any modern game released?  Yes.  You take ANY level in this game, nevermind The Sword and Banford's Mansion, and you have an entire game that is better than most modern releases full games today.  It's that simple.  Stealth, detection of your presence, your awareness of your visibility to your opponents, your realization of levels of detection by voice cues and whether you have a chance of just staying in the shadows all make this games one of the MOST INTENSE battles you will EVER face without ever firing a single shot.  You don't fire fight in this game.  Two blows from a Hammer's hammer and you are done.  No 200% armor, no superhealth, no quad damage, no invulnerability.   It's just you; a mace, a few arrows filled with water and moss and hopefully a flash bomb or two.  It doesn't get more real than this game and you can feel the love and care in every level

content:
18, 2016
Introduction:Thief Gold is a first-person stealth game set in a medieval/fantasy world in which you play as Garrett, a master thief who makes his living by stealing from the rich.  And in order to avoid any spoilers... well, let's just say things get complicated.This is the first game in the Thief series and the extended edition of Thief: The Dark Project.  It includes all of the original game content and features three new missions adapted to the original storyline along with full voice acting and new graphics.TLDR Highlights:+++ Stealth Gameplay and Utilities++ Voice Acting+ Improved (but still old) Graphics-- Slow Start/Story- Wonky Hit-boxes= No wonder it's such a beloved classic!  The old graphics might turn some people off, but if you can get past it, then I highly recommend playing this one.Review:PROS -- The main feature of this game is also the very best thing about it:  stealth gameplay.  I also believe this game is the first to use first-person 3D stealth, which is honestly pretty amazing considering how good it is!  Near the beginning of the game, I was trying to hide in the shadows but it wasn't dark enough thanks to some torches.  Now, this is my very first time ever playing this game, so at first I just made do, thinking this game was far too old to have useful mechanics like removing the torches or, better yet, putting them out somehow.  Sure enough, I found water arrows in my inventory and was able to shoot them at torches to put them out and create more shadows!  There's also rope arrows, noisemaker arrows, moss arrows (to create a quieter surface to walk on), not to mention a blackjack and the need for multiple kinds of lockpicks that somehow made me feel like I was actually picking locks even though the mechanic is extremely simple.  All of this and more are what make the game fun.  Master them, and you'll look be running around like a Master Thief in no time!!Since I never played the original version of this game, I can't compare how the voice acting now compares to how things were then, but I can say that I'm very impressed with it in Thief Gold.  It honestly surprised me right from the start how good it was.  Even the idle chit chat of the variou NPCs were rather good (and often funny lol).As for the graphics, I did end up seeing some images of the old graphics and they have been noticeably improved.  I also recommend using TGTool, which is what I used for some additional improvements, such as 1080 resolution and darker shadows/ambient lighting, making the game even more immersive.CONS -- My biggest and main gripe about the game, however, is the slow start.  This is most likely caused by the pacing of the story.  Some of the first missions were cool and all, but I didn't really feel a sense of purpose.  Sure, there would be little cutscenes that gave me an explanation as to why I was going to this place and stealing that item, but it was lacking in the "big picture" department.  In fact, I started to get bored enough that I almost quit playing.  Fortunately, I stuck it out because the story really gets ramped up by the end.  It sucks that it took so long, but in the end I felt that it was totally worth it, and I can't wait to play the sequel to see what happens next.A much, much smaller issue for me was the hit-boxes when attacking or knocking out the NPCs.  Sometimes I could hit them from a few feet away, and other times I could be right on top of them and miss consistently (maybe hitting somewhere through and behind them).  This wasn't a huge problem, though, because you get a feel for it and the distance required.  Just a by-product of being an old game perhaps.OVERALL -- I've been hearing about this game for a long time, but especially around the time that the new Thief came out not too long ago, and it's been on my list of games to play just as long.  Honestly, I'm very glad I finally got around to it.  It got a little slow there for a bit, but it was worth it.  No wonder it's such a beloved classic!  As long as you can get past the dated graphics, then I definitely recommend playing Thief Gold.

												I can say nothing bad about this game.  Dated graphics?  Pshaw, play the game and it doesn't matter.  This is what medieval Hitman would be like, if going in guns blazing was suicide - open ended from every angle. content:
8, 2016
												This game has it's fair share of problems. You can't play it unless you have Tpatch ,which lets it run better on modern computers. Don't expect anything in terms of graphics ,this is from 1998. This game revolutionized stealth gaming and it's mechanics show in modern gaming. The in-game map was a piece of paper ,which would come up when you press "M" ,similarly to most other games today. The map wouldn't actually show your position ,because it's supposed to be a map that is hand drawn by your player character and it fits the theme ,so I liked that mechanic. I would get lost because of it ,but it's different from most maps and it made you feel like you were there. It also made you look around to figure out where you were ,which actually was really annoying for me. The AI is also extremely stupid and I hated a lot of levels. As much as I hate a lot of mechanics ,this is still an entertaining game. I guess I just don't like it as much as some people because I'm not use to some mechanics. However ,you will get use to it and this is fun.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
r 21, 2016
												Somehow I've missed the thief series back in the day and started to play it only now. I am an old gamer so outdated graphics/gameplay mechanics (they are not outdated in this case and are much better than many new AAA titles have these days)/complicated controls/etc don't bother me at all and I am perfectly fine with older games. HOWEVER. If you are like me and want to jump into thief games for the first time and EXPIRIENCE MASTER THIEF'S story then this game might not be for you.You see, I've finished this game in 27.2 hourse and 90% of the time it's not about thievery... The biggest problem is that first game heavily relies on supernatural elements like zombies, ghosts, and other evil forces. And it's simply not interesting to sneak past those foes nor to steal anything from them. I just couldn't be bothered about those enemies... I didn't feel like it's necessary to be sneaky around them. I slayed them/ran past them, and that completely broke the immersion. It might've been terrifying back in the day but today it's just an annoying experience. So before you play this game ask yourself if the idea of stealing from/sneaking around zombies excites you, because it's a HUGE part of the game.Another big issue for me which some might find very appealing is level design. Thief Gold levels are mostly long and pretty boring maze-like corridors. I'd say it's not interesting to explore 80% of them and I didn't feel like searching for secrets or other mission irrelevant stuff.On the other hand the story is awesome, gameplay mechanics can surpass many AAA titles we have today, the game has many confusing twists and mindblowing elements like Constantine's mansion and it's worth it to at least watch the walkthrough on youtube because it'll be a great entry point into thief series and Garrett's story AND into Thief 2... And that's a whole different story, because I am only 5hrs into Thief 2 and I am telling you that this game is just plain AWESOME. I know that it was like that since the release of the thief 2 and people were separated into two confronting sides: the thief 1 lovers and thief 2 haters AND the thief 2 lovers and thief 1 haters... Well it seems like I am with latter ones.

content:
ry 13, 2015
												Continuing along with some older games and series that I've wanted to play for years, I now play the original Thief game (without having played any of the others, so I am going in order) after just playing System Shock 2, which I loved. Unfortunately, I did not love Thief, nor did I really like it, though I came in with high hopes as I knew that the same developers made System Shock 2.Firstly, I don't mean that the game is inherently bad in many ways. In fact, the majority of the game's design aspects are actually very well done, except for one, which killed the game for me: the level design. Before I get there though, I will first go through everything else I thought about the game, on the positive side:+ The story of the game was very interesting, even just starting with the first cinematic, which got me excited about the game actually going somewhere.+ Garrett is a very likable character and had his own unique attitude, unlike a good amount of protagonists (e.g., the one in System Shock 2 had no character to himself).+ The graphics of the game were decent and didn't bother me, though some things were badly distorted and the mansion in The Sword was ugly.+ The mechanical design of the game is great. I love all of the different items you can use, including intriguing things like the Moss Arrows. The fact that game properly organizes the stealth depending on the material you are walking upon is good, as some current games don't do such a thing. Simple things like directional combat when swinging the sword is good, which again most games don't do nowadays. And changing the difficulty and indirectly changing the objectives of levels is a great idea to add replayability, extending the levels.But sadly, none of the above things helped me get over the level design, which was abysmal. The first level was a generic mansion with nothing special about it, but I was like "Okay, just a way to get you into the stealth." The second level was just as generic, as I didn't find the zombies or caves interesting, and the prison was boring. The third level started making me really dislike the design.At that point, I realized that the levels were mostly generic, giant mazes. Labyrinths, basically! Really, the third level was "unrealistic" in terms of size and really killed my mood. You're walking through the same-looking caves and crypts over and over, in circles. Even though I got through eventually, it was just random waddling and being bored. Most of the levels turned out to be this way. The levels are generally split up into different areas, but all of the rooms or places in a given area usually look the exact same in design. The only levels I ended up enjoying even remotely were the Haunted Cathedral and Strange Bedfellows because of atmosphere.I enjoy stealth games greatly, and I didn't get impatient with the levels because you should take things slow. I'm fine creeping around as needed in such a game. I just got terribly bored and annoyed because most places took forever to find out how to actually get around simply because they were artificial expanses that had no character to them. Occasionally finding notes added some of that, but for the most part, it was all just so boring finding your way through. I know some people will ask if I was bored because I wandered around repeatedly knocking people out, but that was not the case. I was fine with the gameplay and I tried ghosting some levels anyway. It is just the design and layouts that I disliked and ruined everything for me.I mean really, they are just expanses of nothingness... the crypts, the thieves guild, the mansion in The Sword, so on. I loved System Shock 2, and I love other stealth games like the Deus Ex, Metal Gear Solid, and Hitman series, and Dishonored as the most recent example, in which I went through the entire first playthrough not hurting anybody or being seen. But this game's world design made it so boring to play, even though I really was interested (and still am) with the story.And you have the exact opposite with the last level in terms of approach. You go from incredibly open places to the most linear level ever... and just as boring. Fighting the enemies didn't interest me anymore at this point, and in fact, I ended up beating the level in less than 8 minutes (not counting waiting for the ritual at the end) because I simply just jumped along the way, evading all enemies. The only reason it even took that long was because of the water stream.But after the final level, the final cutscene was still very interesting... So I'm hopeful that the next games get better in their levels. I guess I will find out.

												I've tried this game vanilla (well, TFix, GoldtoDark mod to get rid of awful levels, and texture mods so it doesn't look too outdated). This game just strikes me as completely bland with some good ideas. I've seen the whole of the story and it's definitely underwhelming. After running a few action packed missions early on, the levels become these huge, empty labrinths that I got bored traversing. I bumped the difficulty up to Expert and it didn't help with more objectives.My suspicion is that people love these games because they played them like 2 decades ago and they were novel and fresh then. I feel they have not aged well; other games have used these mechanics and to much better, and more fun, effect. I would still rather play Splinter Cell over these games.

number of helpful: 3 of 20 people (15%) found this review helpful
content:
er 2, 2015
												First of all, congrats to the HD Mod and TFix, they are an AMAZING piece of work that enable the game to play in a gorgeous Full Screen with a great resolution and also bring back the cinematics (although I don't understand why they weren't already in the game in the first place...). In addition, keep in mind you will probably have to remap all the controls of the game before playing. At least I had to (playing on AZERTY keyboard). They were utterly broken when I first tried them . Note the game does not support controllers.  Be aware that Thief Gold is not a "turnkey game" in this regard. Back to the game itself, now. I must say I was impressed by all the stealth features Thief had right back in 1998. It's hard to deny the game had a MAJOR impact on gaming. Also, it's not that ugly, and the story and voice acting are pretty decent. HOWEVER, I couldn't bring myself to love it. Not even like it. I found it really tedious to play, and the biggest flaw in my opinion is the fact that you have no real map of the levels, thus resulting in you getting lost for hours inside maze-like corridors and caves. If only I could orientate myself, I'm sure I would have finished the game, but I found it too much of a chore to stay interested. So yeah. Great legacy, appealing game, but eventually too boring. If a mod is released to correct this, I swear I'll try it again.

												Nostalgia is one hell of a drug.Do you enjoy downloading patches and tweaking settings before you can even get the game to work?Do you enjoy tutorials that don't explain anything at all about the game?Do you enjoy incredibly clunky controls that you need to rebind almost entirely?Do you enjoy spending hours running around empty-looking maps with 0 detail to them?Do you enjoy enemies that will detect you with ESP-like accuracy even behind walls if they've already spotted you?Do you enjoy enemies that phase through doors?Do you enjoy out-of-depth undead that shatter the very genre by existing, since they can detect your presence just by being nearby even if in absolute darkness?Do you enjoy relying on 30 second buffs to kill said undead?Do you enjoy old interfaces that don't even tell you what you looted out of chests?Do you enjoy struggling to use something as basic as ladders and doors because of how clunky they are?Do you enjoy having to give up and look maps online to see where in the ugly maze-like building you can find a way to finish the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ level?Do you enjoy running more slowly just because you have a sword out, that you'd be carrying anyways?Do you enjoy having to quicksave constantly because of all the times you'll run around a corner and get spotted by enemies, because the game lacks an autosave function or safe way to peek?Then Thief Gold is for you!I didn't even say anything about graphics because they're honestly something that hardly matters as long as a game is aesthetically pleasing, which I can't complain too much about thief given how old it is, but the maps do feel incredibly empty like a lot of old games would.Didn't say anything about the lack of a reliable map either because the lack of one is supposed to help immersion, and I honestly never found myself even using the vague maps the games provides since they may as well not be there.I gave up playing the game after running around the guild's map for hours and having knocked out every single NPC but still lacking the key I needed to finish the level. All these issues just add up and ultimately make something unenjoyable.I honestly see 0 reason to play this game over any others in the genre other than nostalgia, fanboys will be fanboys and will downvote, sing endless praise, and refuse to see the numerous bad things about their favorite games, but honestly the game is undeserving. It may have been special 18 years ago but it's no longer true. The same seems to be true for a lot of older games having overwhelmingly positive opinions with 0 regards to the many, many negative aspects they may have.

content:
2, 2015
												Well here we are. Thief is ♥♥♥♥. Thats the truth it might have been good in the 90's but know it doesn't hold up for many reasons to numerous to name so here a few cons and pros of the game:ConsGraphics: The graphics are old thats the best way to say it but to be honest graphics quality doesn't really bother me but i know a lot of people are quite into their graphics so thats why its here.Map: I have nothing wrong with map screens if they have some sort of sanity put in them but Garrett god bless him decided to draw them by hand badly so the fun of a non-linear world is ruined by having no way of navigating it.Combat mechanics: Unlike most stealth games nowadays where there is a focus on action over stealth which is good because it gives variety and change to the genre but what makes a stealth game great for me personally is choosing how you would like to carry out your task. Basically whether you want to go in guns blazing or be more sneaky in your execution, Thief doesn't give you this option as the combat mechanics are really bad and trying to fight the guards is like trying to beat a dark souls boss while armed with a wooden stick.Pros:Non-linear map: With reference with my map problems this is feature is sort of ruined but i am still going to add it because maybe you can decrypt Garretts map and get enjoyment out of the exploration of these massive maps. Stealth mechanics: Brilliant, top of the range, amazing.. All words you could use to describe the stealth mechanics: Different materials make varied sounds either loud or soft forcing you to be more careful and thoughtful when you are sneaking through an area, The detail thats gone into the lighting and shadow casting is amazing for such an old game and it really adds to the dark grimy feel of the game but also makes for great stealth moments.In conclusion. I do not recomend Thief as compared to the stealth games we have now a days (Dishonored and Hitman for example) and i know a lot of people are going to disagree with me but know they are doing it because they are filled with nostalgia and nostalgia can only be felt in people that played the orginal thief so if you are looking for a expansion on the orginial game with the same mechanics and atmosphere then go nuts but, if you are like me and have not played it then i would avoid this game as it doesn't hold up to games like Dishonored (my personal favourite stealth game) and Hitman.P.S: Feel free to type as many hate comments as you want i am bored and i could use an inane arugument to liven things up.

r 15, 2015
												I love the idea of stealth games, but unfortunately this game and many others rely on trial and error. It's especially bad here since the combat system is so clunky and broken. Blocking with your sword only works when the game feels like it, and the hit detection is terrible. So combat should be avoided as much as possible. Sneaking up on a guard and knocking them out works most of the time, but other times they'll hear you even though you're moving slowly on carpet. Sometimes you'll get stuck in the middle of a well lit hallway and hear a guard coming that you can't possibly avoid. The only way to get through the game is to fumble around these terrible maps and memorize where these unavoidable hazards are.

content:
ber 29, 2016
												Kinda boring and somewhat janky but Im sure it introduced stuff that wasn't in games or in them much previously. Besides that its kinda boring. The AI isn't really fun to sneak around especially because they are just easier to kill. The combat isn't fun in any way though but then again its supposed to be a stealth game. Its not really hard, its just not very fun or interesting. Sitting in a corner waiting for a guard to leave the area has never been fun to me. The base gameplay is just boring is the issue.Its just so much easier to sneak sometimes and then just kill people who get in the way especially since alot of times you won't realize a guy is right on the other side of a wall until hes already alert. Actually sneaking around kinda sucks and isn't fun particularly because its not easy and super intuitive to control your character aswell as the fact that it can be a bit difficult to know if your going to be spotted or not. Theres certaintly alot of cool mechanics but in reality as a game its just not fun or interesting. Its functional but not fun.I doubt I would have played this game when it was new either, and with no nostalgia to the game I don't care to force myself to play something that just isn't fun. I think the main issue is the mission/map design is terrible aswell as the ingame map being often very unhelpfull.  From what I have seen the level design is nonsensical and confusing with more of the mappers saying "this looks like a fun areal" then it actually being a fun area to play in.Its just boring. Not worth playing without rose tinted glasses and nostalgia. I have seen people online saying you should play it on the hardest difficulty but at that point its not going to be scary for a man like me, just boring AND frustrating.Its only fun to play in very short bursts in between other stuff. Otherwise its just boring and repetative.

content:
y 26, 2014
												1998-2004 were the "MMO addiction" years for me as a gamer.  I remeber when Thief: The Dark Project (1998), Thief II: The Metal Age (2000), and Thief: Deadly Shadows (2004) were released, but add them to the list of other great titles that I neglected for, instead,  endless hours of Ultima Online and Everquest.  Had I given these titles a shot back then, I'm sure that I would have been amazed.However, I think my three days of playing through (not completely) these titles earlier this month came, unfortunately, about 8-10 years too late.  As someone who has aged with the medium over the last 30 years, I can see how amazing these games would have been in their day.  But, much like if I were attempting a first play through of the original two Fallout games (~1998), or my beloved X-Com: UFO Defense (1994), I can't get past the graphical deficiencies and absence of other elements one takes for granted in modern games.The positives:  Great story.  Great voice acting by Stephen Russell portraying anti-hero Garrett.  Ground-breaking stealth play.  Amazing AI.The negatives:  No third person view.  Dated graphics. Problems running on modern systems.   Some games age well.  Civilization III, for example, is as fun to play today as it was at its release in 2001.  Unfortunately, some don't...If you were a fan of the titles back in the day, pick them up for your library when they're on sale.  Otherwise, if you're considering a first-time playthrough, consider waiting until the reboot drops next month (2/28/14).

content:
er 25, 2013
												First game in the thief series, the story revolves around the master thief Garrett as he, unwillingly, gets sucked into a conflict between two of the more powerful factions in The City, a sprawling steampunk metropolis. As the title suggests, the primary goal in the game is to rob a variety of places of their conveniently large stacks of money with your name on it. The game was the first to take FPS game mechanics and apply them to a less combat-oriented game. Though there are plenty of opportunities to fight in the game, the highest difficulty levels require the player to manage to jump through an assortment of hoops without killing anyone. The game doesn't look beautiful by today's standards but does run without a problem usually and this edition contains several new levels not found in the original game. The mission videos, incredibly well done considering the technology limitations at the time, may not play without some custom troubleshooting in some cases but can be viewed on YouTube if it is too much trouble to fix. The game is one of my all-time favorites and the following games are equally well done. The bundle containing the three games released so far is relatively cheap and a fourth game (a reboot) is due to come out this year and is currently available for pre-order.

er 17, 2013
												I hadn't a chance to play the game back in 90's and hasn't played the Steam version for long enough yet, but so far I like it.Main purpose of this review is to cover some FAQ though:1. I didn't find much use for separate run and walk keys -- I remapped keys to the "wsad" pattern, with "w" for run. When I need to walk slowly, I use "shift", works just fine.2. The game itself works OK on Vista (64bit), but without cutscenes. Pressing "Intro" button yields nothing too. I found lack of story/narrative to be quite disquieting so I started looking for a solution.3. As always, there were a lot of bull$hit solutions proposed on the Internet, like TTLG/TFix/etc, but IMNSHO you shouldn't tamper with Steam version using 3rd party patches that may contain every sort of malware while no guarantees whatsoever. The Real Solution for Thief Gold on Vista and Windows 7 is to set "Run this program as administrator" flag on THIEF.EXE (C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\SteamApps\common\thief_gold\THIEF.EXE --> Properties --> Compatibility tab), this brings cutscenes back (don't bother with "Run in WinXP SP2 compatibility" mode, it doesn't cut the mustard).4. You can use resolution higher than 800x600 if you manually edit both cam.cfg and ddfix.ini (TFix boasts that it enables this to be done via in-game Video menu, but I didn't bother to verify).

er 22, 2013
												Very well done game they do not mkae them like this anymore.This game is from the days of no hand holding there are no "way point" markers or any other form of hand holdiong.You have to read the mission objectives and look at the map and figure things out on your own.Thief has some excellent sound effects they still stand the test of time so many years later.You have lots of tools at your disposal variuos types of arrows,rope arrows used for climbing,moss arrows which are aimed at noisy floors and spread a patch of moss on the surafce to allow for silent movement,gas arrows which knock enemies out,fire arrows,noisemarker arrows to name a few.You also have other tools like flash bombs and trip mines.Of course the graphics are very dated but this was cutting edge when it was released.Graphics are not everything despite what the modren gaming industry wants you to think.Thye have thier place but story and gameplay are what is most important and Thief does both very well.You can complete each mission several diffrent ways which adds a lot to replay value.I am the type of player that likes to take my time in a game playing each mission/level the term "speed run" to me is sacrliage.If you like a good story and stealth type gameplay this is a great addtion to your library.

content:
8, 2014
												Being a PC game that's the better half of two decades old, my immediate first impression of Thief was that it was very old and very dated. Graphically speaking, it's nothing an N64 couldn't handle, sound-wise, it feels like someone opened a can of stock "swoosh" sound effects, and after playing it only for a few minutes, I found myself very disappointed indeed. It seemed very bare-bones from the tutorial. There's not even a run button, and the controls are laid out pretty awkwardly. Overall it's hard to jump right in, but then I started to break the surface tension and I realized that underneat the surface of the water was... was a metaphor I'm putting way too much effort into.As it happens, a lot of what makes Thief old is what makes it good. I think this is best exemplified in the map system, chiefly because it's actually a freaking map. Most games don't give you maps nowadays, they give you radars and blip points and arrows and "go-here-if-you-want-to-win"-type things. It makes everything feel very soulless; Thief manages to get around this by giving you the bare minimum. It's pretty neat how this is actually how you would imagine Garrett would put a map together. The game gives you the tools to progression, and you have to interpret them. You never quite know what's going to be around the corner. It's a much better approach than "oh, please, chauffer me to the nearest mundane objective so I can move into your next playground and do the same thing all over again." Cough, Hitman Absolution, cough.The amount of effort that has gone into the levels is very nice; it's easy to immerse yourself into the world. You're given a few details and have to fill in the pieces. Sure, it's dated, but at the end of the day it's a hell of a lot better than almost every stealth game released since... since 1971. Yes, I dare say this game is better than Tennis for Two. Couple that with a fantastically snarky protagonist and a nifty steampunk setting and you're left with a stealth game done the way it should be. This game makes Hitman Absolution cry. Get it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
0, 2013
												Thief: The Dark Project is one of three game released in 1998 that gave birth to the stealth based genre and basically laid the foundation for future games to come. Unlike modern stealth games which give you the option of fighting your way through mobs, you almost always want to stay hidden and strike from the shadows. Mobs usually take quite a few hits to go down and your character Garrett, although an adequate fighter in his own right, is quite squishy and will usually go down really quick. That's not to say that the direct combat method should be avoided, it's actually quite doable, however, the clunky combat system, questionable collision detection and lack of an aiming reticle makes direct combat more trouble than it's worth. The stealth mechanics I thought was innovative although can be quite laughable at times. Thief incorporates a cover system that allows you to conceal yourself in dark, shadowy areas. A "light gem" indicator tells you how visible you are to the mobs around you, however, a flaw with the system is that enemy vision AI is dependent on the light gem, so you can literally stand right in front of a mob and as long as your light gem is indicating that you're hidden, they won't notice you and will walk past you as if you were invisable. Sound also plays a part in stealth with AI responding to noises you make such as footsteps or the impact of a thrown item against a wall. Different floor types can affect the way your footsteps sound. Your gadgets are mostly based around stealth are actually quite creative. Water arrows lets you douse torches to darken a room, moss arrows lets you create soft patches on the ground to walk on to dampen your footsteps, etc. Level design is organic and open ended similar to Deus Ex, giving you more than one way to reach your destintion. If you can get over the outdated graphics (and if you're a real gamer, you should) you'll find that Thief still manages to hold it's own even by today's standards. Solid gameplay, well written story and the atmospheric soundtrack all blend well to create an immersive experience. The game is lengthy enough to keep you playing for quite a while. It's challenging but not unfairly difficult and the lack of a mini map, way points or instant checkpoints shouldn't detract you. It's actually a nice throwback to a time when video games didn't hold your hand as much as it does now. Completing it is very rewarding, especially if you're patient enough to play through and immerse yourself in the whole game and sadly, patience is a trait that most gamers nowaday lack.

content:
y 10, 2014
												Growing up, this was one of my favorite games. I compare it to games like Splinter Cell in the Medieval times. While the game itself was released in 1998, the graphics would be considered outdated in today's standard but they give the game a alternative look when playing it in 2013. What really impressed me about this game was the amount of variables you can control with your weaponry and gadgets and the fact it was made fifteen years ago. Your main character comes equipped with a Sword, Blackjack, and a Bow with a variety of different arrows which really are the focal point of my play style along with a bunch of other gadgets like flash bombs and stuff like that. For example, if you are going for a violent approach within the levels, you can shoot the enemies in the chest with your standard arrow. If you are going for a silent assassin type of approach, you can douse torches with the water arrows, dim the lighted area, and sneak up behind and knockout the enemy with your blackjack. If you are a real pro though, and why this game is called Thief you can go through the whole level/game without killing anything or very few enemies while you steal all the loot that is placed within the levels to buy more gear with.Another great element of this game is the fact they added undead and alienesque creatures in the later levels and it really shows in the difficulty as you progress through the game. There are some minor flaws such as enemy movement getting 'stuck on walls' and things like that but it really doesn't bother me because of how this game has held itself up against the test of time. It is a great addition to anyone's Steam library.

content:
9, 2013
												Thief is probably one of those games that gets overlooked. It's a shame because this is probably one of the most memorable, unique, gaming experiences. In 1998, the Dark Engine was ahead of its time. Modern games today would rival Thief with its unique and sprawling levels, its interesting story, and wholly unique gameplay. Being able to truly be free in choice to handle mission objects is fresh, even by today's standards. Sound is an important factor. Dropping in on conversations can lead useful clues. The game boasts some really terrific audio. As good as the audio is the gameplay is where it really shines. I will never forget the first nerve-racking moment where an alerted guard begins sweeping the room, looking for me as I, the player hunch in the shadows praying he doesn't find me. You do have access variety of weapons and gadgets and  your arsenal gives a multiple means to accomplish goals but combat is largely a risky venture. You are a thief, not a warrior. These sort of experiences seem incredibly rare in modern games.In summy, for the cheap price, you are getting an amazing gameplay experience. If you find yourself wanting more, you'll find a fantastic community of dedicated Thief fans over on Thief theCircle. Fans are still creating Fan Missions, and hell, there is even a full blown expansion for Thief 2. Get this game, you won't be disappointed.

content:
1, 2014
												This was a gamechanger, in my opinion. Elements from the original Thief would be incorporated in countless games over the coming years. To this day, this title, to me, is one of the most influential games of all time.The plot is unique but takes a few missions to set up. Most of the graphics are on par for the year - nothing special with the exception of the lighting. The game heavily focuses on environments - the light around you, the floors you walk on, the noise of the actions you make. Sound is beautiful in this game - surround sound is a MUST so look into OpenAL or fixes for Creative Alchemy if you need to. Combat is straight forward. The gameplay itself, played as its meant to be played, is strictly about avoiding conflict and remaining undetected. When combat is mandatory, it's usually against nonsentient creatures (undead, magical creatures, etc). Overall, I can recommend this game to -anyone-. It is difficult at times, but it is one of the greatest games of all time.

												Great mechanics, good world building, interesting setting. It rewards patience and planning effectively. You can't handle combat very well especially on Expert difficulty, and the game was purely designed around stealth which works well with it's multitude of ways to explore the city. Well crafted atmosphere that easily immerses you, especially as you continue forward. The music really fits the themes of the levels well, and changes depending on where you are. A recommended game not only to appreciate the stealth mechanics and ingenuity of itself, but to appreciate the non-tact story telling and overall craft that went into making this. This is the best game I've ever played.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
er 10, 2013
												YES, my favourite game of all times!!!I remember the day I first played the demo of this amazing game. A dark and rainy day, as if it was made for gaming. I finished the demo after 2 hours. I explored as much as possible.And played it through again after finishing.The day the game finally came out I stood up early and was at the shop an hour before they opened to buy that game. I was not disappointed.Since that day I have played "Thief: the dark project" more than 30 times. No other game ever made me so addicted. I made 1-2 speedruns for my own, explored the hell out of the game, played every difficulty. I love beeing a stealthy thief... Even my brother still plays it, though most old games he defines as "ugly junk".Ok, enough of being a fanboy. Let's go to the core of the game.Technical:You are right if you think that this game is looking old. The game was made in the late 1990s and you can see that games developed quite much since then.(Thanks to a quite active modder-scene several mods have been released that make the game better looking.)In my case I don't care about that, because the game lives by a fascinating atmosphere, not by it's graphics.The sounds are amazing for the time being released. It is quite interesting how "surround" the sound is. And well, this game is the example for "footsteps". Listening to them you can define how far an enemy is, how loud you are and how much attaction you will get. So leave your stepdance-shoes alone and take the "sneakers"...Gameplay:The controls work quite good, the stealth system is the best I've seen in a game so far.You should use the shadows (It has some reason the subtittle is "the DARK project"), avoid noise, steal as much as you can and never be seen by the guards. Else the game will be quite short... So stay in the dark.You will see it takes a lot of patience for this game. Looking for gaps in the patrols, seeking the dark corners of a house, most time hidden. If you love modern shooters do me a favour and buy them, but not THIS game...The "hud" of the game has a small bar, that shows you how visible you are. A revolutionary concept in it's release. Did I mention: "stay in the dark"?Loot is essential to buy stuff for the next level. Every worthy thing you steal will be sold and the money will be added to your funds. Buy a moss-arrow? Go for it. Buy some flash-bombs? Here you go. You need an water arrow to put out torches? You're welcome.Story:Well, I won't spoiler anything here now. You are a thief in the "middle ages". Stay in the dark and steal as much as you can. The rest you will see...To come to an end:A great game (in my case THE greatest game of all times) worth buying it (even after so many years)..........Did I mention: Stay in the dark?

content:
9, 2013
												Thief is probably one of those games that gets overlooked. It's a shame because this is probably one of the most memorable, unique, gaming experiences. In 1998, the Dark Engine was ahead of its time. Modern games today would rival Thief with its unique and sprawling levels, its interesting story, and wholly unique gameplay. Being able to truly be free in choice to handle mission objects is fresh, even by today's standards. Sound is an important factor. Dropping in on conversations can lead useful clues. The game boasts some really terrific audio. As good as the audio is the gameplay is where it really shines. I will never forget the first nerve-racking moment where an alerted guard begins sweeping the room, looking for me as I, the player hunch in the shadows praying he doesn't find me. You do have access variety of weapons and gadgets and  your arsenal gives a multiple means to accomplish goals but combat is largely a risky venture. You are a thief, not a warrior. These sort of experiences seem incredibly rare in modern games.In summy, for the cheap price, you are getting an amazing gameplay experience. If you find yourself wanting more, you'll find a fantastic community of dedicated Thief fans over on Thief theCircle. Fans are still creating Fan Missions, and hell, there is even a full blown expansion for Thief 2. Get this game, you won't be disappointed.
