												1st of all: LOL @ people buying a 15+ year old game and complaining about graphics and/or OS-issuesA quick search and you'll find the TG-Tool, which helps a lot. There's also a decent Thief Gold HD Mod out there. But Haters Gonna Hate, so i'll keep focus on the review.So here comes my 'old fart story': I remember, when a friend told me about this "new game" and after school he showed me the demo he got from a magazine. I never played a single demo level so many times and i couldn't wait to get the full game. Long story short, it was a great game back then!Fast forward to the new millennium and games with brilliant graphics but (mostly) mediocre gameplay. Nowadays i rarely play games, but when i stumble over a teaser for the new Thief, i checked Steam for the old trilogy and downloaded it without hesitation. What can i say ... i still love it.The game is just awesome and the missions are still brilliant (even my 'steam record' says 0.1 hrs, i played 5 missions on expert level so far) and a lot of fun to play. I'm know, that not every one can play 'slow games' like Thief, so if you're a shooter-loving action-junkie, you probably won't get happy. This game is about waiting in dark corners, sneaking around and being patient.The atmosphere is the best part of the game, so when you play the game while watching TV or browse internet-porn, you won't have much fun either (well, depends what porns you find). But if you have the right setup (dark room & headphones) and the right attitude, you can enjoy one of the best games of all time (and probably the best 'stealth game ever').

content:
y 8, 2015
												I absolutely LOVED this game. There is no other series out on the market that really puts you into the shoes of a masterful thief like this one does. I love the stealth and planning required in this game. You are often dropped into the maps with little hint on what to do, but there are usually multiple ways to go about completing a level which is great. It certainly does not hold your hand like modern games do, and because it is old it also runs perfectly on computers and laptops not made for gaming. If you love the stealth aspect of the game, then higher difficulty settings will work better for you and aso give you more gameplay content to complete. If you can't help but kill some guards/civilians, then the normal difficulty setting is best for you. But the game is still hard even on that mode haha! I definitely recommend learning how to use arrow ropes properly because they will be your best friend in a lot of the later maps/levels. The only problem I really had with this game is that for some reason to cutscenes wouldn't run on my pc, which was a minor inconvenience because I had to go watch them on youtube. This may not be the case for everyone, but after looking it up I know I'm not the only person who had that issue. However, cutscenes aren't too important if all you care about is the gameplay itself. Overall, I'd give this game a 9.5/10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
y 24, 2014
												Released in 1999 Thief Gold is the re-release of 1998's Thief: The Dark Project the wonderful game from the sadly now defunct Looking Glass Studios.  Originally Thief was known as Dark Camelot and intended to be an action RPG type of game and you can see throughout this game where they recycled content from that original game - ie medieval influenced missions.  it later morphed into Dark Project when they found that the stealth aspect (championed by Paul Neurath) was a lot more entertaining and that a game involving stealth and thievery would be a better option.Rather than being a straight re-issue of the game it was an early form of what we now know as GOTY editions. It includes 3 extra levels: The Mage Towers, The Thieves Guild and Song of the Caverns.  In addition to extra missions it also tweaked the standard missions some minor tweaks in most and then a couple of levels receiving reworking notably The Sword (added more area - ie Little Big World), Undercover (story changes), The Lost City (enemy and story changes) and Down in the Bonehoard is retextured.  Furthermore Thief Gold moves the version up to 1.37 from T:DP's final version of v1.33.  On the old discs you also got a preview of Thief II and of course the additional mission the Blooper Reel (Lord Baffords Manor featuring entertaining bugs and humorous content)At present the cut scenes do not function on some systems, notably Windows 7, there are various work arounds available - they can be found over at ttlg.com (file is called Tfix_1.18c) or if you so wish you can always Youtube the Thief cut scenes.  I highly recommend you watch the cut scenes, not only do they advance the story and reveal a lot of twists and turns related to it but they are also beautifully crafted and remain a joy to watch.The concept of Thief is simple, achieve the mission objectives by the use of stealth.  Stealth in this game pertains to use of shadows, sound and movement.  To aid you in this you have a light gem in the lower section of the screen that indicates the amount of light you are currently exposed in.  Sound is highly important and was one of the first games, if not the first where sound was just as important as what you could see.  Footsteps on varied surfaces, the sound of patrolling guards and ambient noise all add a rich and extra layer of gameplay.  You need to take these elements and work within them or bend them to your favour to achieve your objectives.The game is set within The City, a steampunkish type era, like the Victorian era on the cusp of industrialisation.  The City itself is moody, bleak and dangerous, the perfect playground for the adventurous. There are several factions within The City all vying for control, the mysterious Baron of the City remains aloof, a figure of power and control but not involved directly.  The ambience of The City is beautiful and it's success is largely due to the presentation of The City, both aurally and visually. The story that unwinds also fleshes out The City.Comparisons can be made to Dunwall from Dishonoured and Dishonoured does indeed play like a Thief game and has that ambience, albeit the focus is on assassination and not on stealth and theft.  Dunwall though is the victim of politics that goes up to the highest level, The City feels more alive though.   There is no apocalyptic plague sweeping the streets and the highest power is not overtly tyrannical but the various factions do give "layers" to The City, it feels like it has more depth and soul than Dunwall ever had, it is an entity in itself.The visuals are nothing exciting but they are effective enough.  The sound though is truly a thing of sublime beauty.  This is the first game where it was essential to have sound enabled and if possible to have a dedicated sound card (that again has kind of died out thanks to integrated sound on motherboards).  From the fabulous sound ambience to the classical Loot sound it is all very stylised and very integral to the Thief experience.  It must be said that the talents of the voice actor for Garrett, Mr Stephen Russell truly stand out as one of the greatest in gaming. He gives Garrett the very jaded, near misanthropic character that makes the game feel so immersive.  Garrett feels like what you would expect to be a product of hard life within The City it is conveyed wonderfully.  It is wonderful to hear Garrett go into his internal monologues during missions, throwing story, character and enjoyment at you.  Be warned though after sneaking through a level only hearing footsteps and ambience you may jump off of your chair in fright the first time his voice unexpectedly booms out at you. The difficulty levels change objectives and throw in variables such as not killing anyone and collecting a certain minimum amount of loot. At the easier difficulty levels it can be easy to roll in and kill all the enemies in a level, but by far the biggest challenge is to play on the Expert setting and try to adhere to the rules of Ghosting - ie don't let anyone see you, leave things as you found them (except for things you need to loot to achieve the objectives), don't knock anyone out even relock doors you pass through etc.. By and large the rules of Ghosting are self-imposed, a fun challenge to yourself, but a rewarding one.  Consider the missions (levels) to be a big playground at your disposal.The controls are standard controls for the era and you may find you will want to tweak them to match what you are used to playing today - ie alternating strafe and lean keys for instance and changing the walk and backwards buttons etc.  Combat is straightforward - use your bow to snipe targets or to shoot a variety of specialty arrows - water arrows to douse torches, moss arrows to soften the noise on surfaces, rope arrows to climb to other areas, fire arrows to destroy things, broad head to kill enemies/make a noise, noisemaker arrows to create a distraction etc..  The Sword play is simple, space to block and primary attack to swing the sword.  Hold it down for a stronger strike. By far the most useful tool though is the Blackjack.  This item is used to render guards unconscious.  Slip up behind a guard raise your blackjack and then bring it down upon their head.  Then get rid of the unconscious body - be aware that placing a body near a fireplace or in even a small amount of water will probably result in death to the unconscious party - bad if you are trying to achieve a no-kill objective.  So while dumping that body into an unlit fireplace may seem great, it won't be if a servant comes and lights it up :PAt the time of release the original Thief was described as a sneak 'em up (as opposed to shoot 'em up) and it is the precursor of all stealth games that you see today.  The graphics have not aged well, mods can fix that if you so choose and the controls can be quite archaic. But the story remains as beautiful as ever and there is a great deal of satisfaction to be garnered from this game. The reboot of the series, Thief, is to be released soon and while the reboot doesn't follow on from these stories - it certainly seems to take ideas from the series.If you enjoy stealth games, games with an interesting story and enjoy a challenge, then Thief: Gold is a game for you.  It does look dated now but it remains as enjoyable as ever to play.  Make sure you apply the fixes to get the cutscenes working (and improved resolution options) to really improve the gameplay experience for you. Tweak the controls as you need and you should find yourself become immersed in the depths of The City very quickly.  From the first time you pickpocket a guard of a key, hear that chiming loot sound or even your first close shave with your heart pounding in your throat you will be hooked on the game.  It really is a gem of gaming.

												It is amazing to see how such a well crafted game still holds up to our modern gaming society through the amazingly constructed environment with smart and big level maps.  I personally found the game quite long.  Each level is just as the other (These levels can be massive!!!), walk into a building/area, each unique to one another, just to find that there a multiple ways to complete most of the quests. ber 10, 2013
EDIT: The text below was written before Steam Recommendations became Steam Reviews.Thief is a masterpiece in its genre, that's a fact. It was released in 1998 and can compete with many modern games that have a similar concept. Great story, truly amazing music and cutscenes, steampunk vibe, scary locations and enemies. I remember when I was a kid (like Garrett, the protagonist when he tried to rob the Keeper) I couldn't play the game because I was so afraid of zombies that couldn't be killed without using holy water. Even now I had problems, maybe not with zombies but with spiders. There are so many of them throughout the game and even though the graphics are outdated they are as horrid as in the real world. The Gold version adds a couple of new missions that are of very high quality like the rest of the game. Thief is a FPS game, it's possible to kill/knock unconcious every enemy the player meets, but it requires a lot of patience and cunning. Thief is scary and weird, but the efforts are always rewarded. Steal from the rich and give to yourself!

												Patch it first: http://www.ttlg.com/forums/showthread.php?t=134733I had to add this because the cutscenes don't work for some reason when you launch the game. It's a simple patch, though, just download it, locate the game listed under your directory, and TFix does the rest for you. Do I think this game should be released without problems like the cutscenes simply not working? Yes, I do. Do I think it deserves a bad review? No, just because the cutscenes don't work doesn't mean this game should be flagged as one to be avoided. That's really the only problem I had, and even if there wasn't a patch for it I'd still recommend this game because it's really just a minute issue in my opinion. The gameplay itself is pretty solid, and for its time the stealth mechanics were incredible before stealth in video games was even popularized. Overall, the game is pretty definitive of a first person stealth game centered on a steampunk setting done right. Looking Glass Studios basically demonstrate how they were an underrated development team with an overwhelming amount of talent.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
20
												In the small genre of stealth there is only a handfull of truly great games. Not only is this game one of the original classics but also one of the best(including the 2nd&3rd) if not THE best. The game takes place in a world that is a mixture of gothic fantasy, steampunk and, sort of 1600s- 1800s Europe. No guns though! But that's a good thing. this world includes all kinds of monsters, creatures and different types of humans. Most humans are designed to be a hilarious sort rather than serious. Events and lore are explained in 4 main ways: from cutscenes that have a awesome and beautiful 2D art style. Letters and books. The main character also comments on things himself, his name is Garret and has a witty sarcastic sort of tone and is a joy to listen to. And finally you can listen to other people talking both to themselves and others to learn things provided you are  sneaky and dont disturb them. The writing is suberb and really adds to the game, you actually want to listen and read. The voice acting is brilliant both the serious and humorous. Even the monsters sound awesome and some cases horrifying. The game and two sequels are full of atmosphere, the music, the sounds, the lighting is all done so well. Still to this day have some of the best sound design. At many points this game feels like a horror game which many "actual" horror games cant even  say. The guards will sometimes go off on a tirade about random stuff which adds a lot of charm and shows how much fun the developers had making this game. There's also a few different factions you meet, the Pagans who are nature worshipers, very occult stuff, the Hammerites basically medieval Christians and the keepers who i wont say anything about. Very interesting and different all of them. Now onto the meat of the game. The level design and the gameplay. So in Thief before every mission you will get a overview of what will be in store and then have the ability to use the shop where you can buy all sorts of things using the money you collected in the last mission so it helps to be a perfectionist and get most of the loot. You can even purchase tips if you think you will need some help. The game has several difficulties, i highly recommend the highest for all 3 games. It wont be insanely hard for you, just gotta be patient and plan out your stealth. The levels are fairly big and have many paths, they're also quite varied so you won't get tired of them. When it comes to your gear, you have a blackjack for knocking people out, a sword for combat which you'd prefer to avoid, it's not like dishonored, Garret is no amazing superhero. You also have a bow with standard arrows, along with some magic ones, water arrows for putting out fire, fire arrows for destroying stuff and killing, and moss arrows so you dont make too much noise on harder surfaces. You go through the mission always looking for the main objective but depending the place Garret will also mention other things you might want to check out, grab, or do. Sometimes will find bonus side events or objectives while looking around. It all works really well! When it comes down to it, just explore a cool level full of thick atmosphere and steal things! Even today the game itself looks fine, levels have a pretty and interesting art design. Although the Ai at times can be stupid and very easy to exploit which i only recommend trying after playing at least one time legit. Overall the game is a fun, memorable stealth game that feels like an adventure, sometimes fantasy, sometimes horror. And has huge replay value. I can't recommend this enough, they truly don't make them like this anymore. And if you like this one i recommend the 2nd and 3rd game. Thief 2: The Metal Age and Theif 3: Deadly Shadows. They change some things in those games but the core writing and gameplay is there.

												Thief is a glorious game no matter what age you are, or date it is.The first of many games that taught us - not through words, but actions - to hide. content:
7, 2012
												As one of the first 3D stealth games, Thief Gold does a surprising number of things really well, even after only 5 missions. Dynamic lighting combines with an amazing stereo sound (get a headset) to create an intuitive atmosphere, where you're sneaking from shadow to cover, nicking things and conking guards on the head. Levels are huge, exploration is huge (no invisible walls), and the tools/arrows you have are large and varied. Top it up with a spooky, tense soundtrack and you have a real gem.It's not all great: graphics are ofc 1998, enemy AI isn't perfect (enemies don't notice patrolling guards go missing or torches going out), the Steam version doesn't show cutscenes (which is what Youtube's for), you backtrack a bunch, item menu is a bit clunky, but all these minor setbacks don't stop it from being a great game. It takes a while to get into, but if you love nicking someone's bag of coins before whacking him on the head, it's well worth $10.Thief Gold: cus u steal gold :-)

content:
y 10, 2014
												Growing up, this was one of my favorite games. I compare it to games like Splinter Cell in the Medieval times. While the game itself was released in 1998, the graphics would be considered outdated in today's standard but they give the game a alternative look when playing it in 2013. What really impressed me about this game was the amount of variables you can control with your weaponry and gadgets and the fact it was made fifteen years ago. Your main character comes equipped with a Sword, Blackjack, and a Bow with a variety of different arrows which really are the focal point of my play style along with a bunch of other gadgets like flash bombs and stuff like that. For example, if you are going for a violent approach within the levels, you can shoot the enemies in the chest with your standard arrow. If you are going for a silent assassin type of approach, you can douse torches with the water arrows, dim the lighted area, and sneak up behind and knockout the enemy with your blackjack. If you are a real pro though, and why this game is called Thief you can go through the whole level/game without killing anything or very few enemies while you steal all the loot that is placed within the levels to buy more gear with.Another great element of this game is the fact they added undead and alienesque creatures in the later levels and it really shows in the difficulty as you progress through the game. There are some minor flaws such as enemy movement getting 'stuck on walls' and things like that but it really doesn't bother me because of how this game has held itself up against the test of time. It is a great addition to anyone's Steam library.

content:
er 10, 2013
												YES, my favourite game of all times!!!I remember the day I first played the demo of this amazing game. A dark and rainy day, as if it was made for gaming. I finished the demo after 2 hours. I explored as much as possible.And played it through again after finishing.The day the game finally came out I stood up early and was at the shop an hour before they opened to buy that game. I was not disappointed.Since that day I have played "Thief: the dark project" more than 30 times. No other game ever made me so addicted. I made 1-2 speedruns for my own, explored the hell out of the game, played every difficulty. I love beeing a stealthy thief... Even my brother still plays it, though most old games he defines as "ugly junk".Ok, enough of being a fanboy. Let's go to the core of the game.Technical:You are right if you think that this game is looking old. The game was made in the late 1990s and you can see that games developed quite much since then.(Thanks to a quite active modder-scene several mods have been released that make the game better looking.)In my case I don't care about that, because the game lives by a fascinating atmosphere, not by it's graphics.The sounds are amazing for the time being released. It is quite interesting how "surround" the sound is. And well, this game is the example for "footsteps". Listening to them you can define how far an enemy is, how loud you are and how much attaction you will get. So leave your stepdance-shoes alone and take the "sneakers"...Gameplay:The controls work quite good, the stealth system is the best I've seen in a game so far.You should use the shadows (It has some reason the subtittle is "the DARK project"), avoid noise, steal as much as you can and never be seen by the guards. Else the game will be quite short... So stay in the dark.You will see it takes a lot of patience for this game. Looking for gaps in the patrols, seeking the dark corners of a house, most time hidden. If you love modern shooters do me a favour and buy them, but not THIS game...The "hud" of the game has a small bar, that shows you how visible you are. A revolutionary concept in it's release. Did I mention: "stay in the dark"?Loot is essential to buy stuff for the next level. Every worthy thing you steal will be sold and the money will be added to your funds. Buy a moss-arrow? Go for it. Buy some flash-bombs? Here you go. You need an water arrow to put out torches? You're welcome.Story:Well, I won't spoiler anything here now. You are a thief in the "middle ages". Stay in the dark and steal as much as you can. The rest you will see...To come to an end:A great game (in my case THE greatest game of all times) worth buying it (even after so many years)..........Did I mention: Stay in the dark?

7, 2012
												As one of the first 3D stealth games, Thief Gold does a surprising number of things really well, even after only 5 missions. Dynamic lighting combines with an amazing stereo sound (get a headset) to create an intuitive atmosphere, where you're sneaking from shadow to cover, nicking things and conking guards on the head. Levels are huge, exploration is huge (no invisible walls), and the tools/arrows you have are large and varied. Top it up with a spooky, tense soundtrack and you have a real gem.It's not all great: graphics are ofc 1998, enemy AI isn't perfect (enemies don't notice patrolling guards go missing or torches going out), the Steam version doesn't show cutscenes (which is what Youtube's for), you backtrack a bunch, item menu is a bit clunky, but all these minor setbacks don't stop it from being a great game. It takes a while to get into, but if you love nicking someone's bag of coins before whacking him on the head, it's well worth $10.Thief Gold: cus u steal gold :-)

												1st of all: LOL @ people buying a 15+ year old game and complaining about graphics and/or OS-issuesA quick search and you'll find the TG-Tool, which helps a lot. There's also a decent Thief Gold HD Mod out there. But Haters Gonna Hate, so i'll keep focus on the review.So here comes my 'old fart story': I remember, when a friend told me about this "new game" and after school he showed me the demo he got from a magazine. I never played a single demo level so many times and i couldn't wait to get the full game. Long story short, it was a great game back then!Fast forward to the new millennium and games with brilliant graphics but (mostly) mediocre gameplay. Nowadays i rarely play games, but when i stumble over a teaser for the new Thief, i checked Steam for the old trilogy and downloaded it without hesitation. What can i say ... i still love it.The game is just awesome and the missions are still brilliant (even my 'steam record' says 0.1 hrs, i played 5 missions on expert level so far) and a lot of fun to play. I'm know, that not every one can play 'slow games' like Thief, so if you're a shooter-loving action-junkie, you probably won't get happy. This game is about waiting in dark corners, sneaking around and being patient.The atmosphere is the best part of the game, so when you play the game while watching TV or browse internet-porn, you won't have much fun either (well, depends what porns you find). But if you have the right setup (dark room & headphones) and the right attitude, you can enjoy one of the best games of all time (and probably the best 'stealth game ever').

content:
ber 28, 2016
												I haven't finished the game yet, I'm trying to make it last. A "pros and cons" breakdown isn't working for me for this, so let's call this "Observations on Thief Gold Thus Far":Thief Gold got stealth right. The invisibility that some games call "stealth" for thieves, rogues and what have you, the standing in broad daylight directly in an enemy's eyeline and practically under their nose, without cover, and going unseen because a skill score is high enough, just doesn't do it for me. Actual invisibililty doing that is fine, that's a separate beast, but it doesn't feel like "skill" when it works that way. In Thief, there's an element of logic to stealth; the character Garrett has some training that's meant to make him better at it than the average Joe, and there's some limited tools (including improvised ones) to help, but stealth's otherwise based on player skill and common sense, not on a stat score. If you decide to waltz Garrett right in front of a guard in a well-lit room, better get those track shoes laced up tight!Thief is a game that uses sound well. Not just for ambience and effect, but for clues, and also as a warning that you're walking into trouble -- or that trouble's about to walk into you. Normally I have videos or music or maybe an audiobook going in the background when playing a game solo, but Thief plays best horror-game style: with the sound turned up and no distractions.If you hate mazelike levels and "maps" that are a few next to useless scribbles, this might not be the game for you. The thing is... I've never been a fan myself of bumbling around trying to find my way from X to Y in games where a single level goes well over the one-hour mark of wondering what I'm missing. (Or two hours; I admit it, I could get lost in my own backyard.)  But in Thief Gold, wandering around trying to get to my next goal has yet to make me want to stop playing -- take a break and come back fresh, yes, that's helped, but not quit for good -- or resort to looking up walkthroughs. With one exception, where I looked up just enough to be sure I wasn't up against a game glitch rather than a challenge (I wasn't), and then hastily closed the page. I'm not afraid to use game walkthroughs to get past a portion of a game that just isn't fun, or to drop a game that's become mostly the "not fun" bits, so it says something in Thief's favor that even with help at my fingertips, I didn't want to use it and I'm still playing the game. I think it's that there's stuff besides the way to the next main goal to find that makes the difference, be it shiny loot, a bit of overheard NPC dialogue, or a scene or a document that tells a piece of a story. (Documents aren't overdone in Thief by the way, and cutscenes are mostly a thing relegated to the beginnings and ends of levels where I'd say they belong. Instead, there are places where things can be heard as Garrett approaches, be it a conversation between NPCs, or... other things I'm not going to spoil...) It feels like there's actually stuff to find besides that which checks off the little boxes on the Objectives page, and that's nice. This is the other aspect of Thief that made a high-def mod nice to have.   So for the price, even if mazelike layouts aren't your favorite thing, I'd say it's still worth giving it a try.On looting the place:  Oh, how proud I was upon finishing a level, thinking I'd patiently and persistently gotten ALL the loot in that level! That lasted until I checked the Stats at the level-complete screen and learned I'd gotten three-fifths of the loot at best. *Bwaahh-bwaahh*... It was refreshing, after a number of more recent games left me feeling like the designers had forgotten how to challenge the player in ways besides beefing enemy health and damage, or allowing AI opponents to "cheat the system" for an advantage. (Or the ultimate challenge-designing cop-out in my eyes, counting on online PVP modes to provide the bulk of challenge in a game -- in which opponents cheating the system, because it's the lazy way to win, is often even more of an issue than with AI.) Thief is a solo game that doesn't feel like it has to cheat to challenge me, and I admire that about it. I also like that looting every last shiny object is optional, and that the nature of the character -- a thief -- encourages weighing pragmatic survival considerations against the fact he's, well, a thief, which makes looting the place a survival consideration too. After spending awhile huddled in a tiny cupboard while a guard stomped about just inches away, growling about what happens to thieves when they're caught, and having taken so many risks already, would Garrett leave with what he's got? Or look for more? Or stalk that guard, cosh him, stuff him in that very same cupboard, and then look for more? I had surprisingly little trouble getting the game running on a recent computer despite its age, so props to whoever may have had a hand in that. I'm having a lot of fun finally playing Thief Gold, if that's not already evident; it's a game I missed out on when it was new, and it's proving worth the wait.

content:
28, 2013
												Shortly put? This is one of the best stealth games that you will ever play.But for those who want more than that:Gameplay: Let's put it like this: If I was ever going to become a thief and steal anything that's not nailed down in a fortified palace, I imagine it would feel pretty damn like Thief Gold. What I love about the stealth in this game is that it's realistic. While a game like Metal Gear Solid decks you out with a soliton radar and boots that make no noise whatsoever, Thief forces you to rely on your own senses and instinct. You must lean to see enemies around a corner. You must be aware of the surfaces you walk on, as certain surfaces make more noise than others. You must freaking press your ears against doors to HEAR if there's an enemy in the other room! It's absolutely fantastic and incredibly enjoyable. 10/10Soundtrack:Not so much a soundtrack, more like ambience. It makes sense that blaring music would feel intrinsically wrong in a stealth game and Thief realises this, so music is kept to a minimal. Where there is music however, it perfectly suits the scenario- case in point the mission in the opera house. On the other hand, there are instances where the same loud music is repeated again and again, and you find stealth has suddenly become much harder: in a negative way this time (case in point- the freaking first part of the downwind thieves guild mission). 7/10Story: Captivating. The first few missions feel, admittedly, a little disjointed and unrelated, but eventually the main plot reveals itself and it is a spectacle to behold. I for one very much enjoyed it. 8/10Extra content:Thief Gold improves on The Dark Project in that it brings three new missions. One completely unrelated to the story and two that fit nicely into the story (The mages tower mission is probably the best mission in the game!) 9/10Overall: See the first few sentences of this recommendation. 10/10

content:
er 28, 2016
												Tired of saving the world, battling enemy armies, exploring galaxies? Do you want to experience something different? Do you want to do something you shouldn't be doing? Go somewhere you shouldn't be? Do you want to play a game that had a huge influence on video games design and stood the test of time?This absolute gem of a stealth game from Looking Glass Studios (who are responsible for games like System Shock and Ultima Underworld) wasn't meant to have stealth mechanics until few months away from the game's release!It’s one of the first FPS in which you are expected to be quick, sneaky and avoid enemies at all cost and not go guns blazing. This is a brilliant piece of game design. Amazing sound engine that is more advanced than most of the engines in games today. It runs great on modern hardware thanks to unofficial patch TFix. You simply have to play the game on headphones and turn on OpenAL and EAX. It puts modern games to shame.The game world has it’s logic and exprects you to follow it. You can’t move through a corridor because you make too much noise walking on the marble floors? Use moss to muffle your steps. You can’t sneak because the room is well lit and the guards will spot you? Use water arrow to put out torches. The path is set out. How you choose to reach the destination is really up to you.Garret, the game’s protagonist, doesn’t want to save the world. All he wants is to be left alone and get on with his life. He want to use his skills to steal loot. And there’s plenty of it hidden throughout the levels. Without spoiling the plot … Garret and his master thief skills get him into something much bigger than he ever anticipated.Amazing atmosphere, various items to help you during heists and well designed missions (mansions, cathedral, mines, prison) that can be explored in several different ways. You completed the game? The internet will provide you with multiple fan-made missions that will keep you busy until you pick up … Thief II.It's simply a masterful game that let's you become a master thief. I can’t imagine what stealth game genre would look like if it weren’t for Looking Glass Studios and their Thief: The Dark Project. I played this game when it was released and having hundreds hours under my belt I can safely say this game is still as immersive now as it was in 1998.Solid 9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
er 10, 2013
												YES, my favourite game of all times!!!I remember the day I first played the demo of this amazing game. A dark and rainy day, as if it was made for gaming. I finished the demo after 2 hours. I explored as much as possible.And played it through again after finishing.The day the game finally came out I stood up early and was at the shop an hour before they opened to buy that game. I was not disappointed.Since that day I have played "Thief: the dark project" more than 30 times. No other game ever made me so addicted. I made 1-2 speedruns for my own, explored the hell out of the game, played every difficulty. I love beeing a stealthy thief... Even my brother still plays it, though most old games he defines as "ugly junk".Ok, enough of being a fanboy. Let's go to the core of the game.Technical:You are right if you think that this game is looking old. The game was made in the late 1990s and you can see that games developed quite much since then.(Thanks to a quite active modder-scene several mods have been released that make the game better looking.)In my case I don't care about that, because the game lives by a fascinating atmosphere, not by it's graphics.The sounds are amazing for the time being released. It is quite interesting how "surround" the sound is. And well, this game is the example for "footsteps". Listening to them you can define how far an enemy is, how loud you are and how much attaction you will get. So leave your stepdance-shoes alone and take the "sneakers"...Gameplay:The controls work quite good, the stealth system is the best I've seen in a game so far.You should use the shadows (It has some reason the subtittle is "the DARK project"), avoid noise, steal as much as you can and never be seen by the guards. Else the game will be quite short... So stay in the dark.You will see it takes a lot of patience for this game. Looking for gaps in the patrols, seeking the dark corners of a house, most time hidden. If you love modern shooters do me a favour and buy them, but not THIS game...The "hud" of the game has a small bar, that shows you how visible you are. A revolutionary concept in it's release. Did I mention: "stay in the dark"?Loot is essential to buy stuff for the next level. Every worthy thing you steal will be sold and the money will be added to your funds. Buy a moss-arrow? Go for it. Buy some flash-bombs? Here you go. You need an water arrow to put out torches? You're welcome.Story:Well, I won't spoiler anything here now. You are a thief in the "middle ages". Stay in the dark and steal as much as you can. The rest you will see...To come to an end:A great game (in my case THE greatest game of all times) worth buying it (even after so many years)..........Did I mention: Stay in the dark?
